title: 111_hr4476
content: The Act titled "Equity in Government Compensation Act of 2010" is cited in Section 1. Congressional findings are outlined in Section 2. The Congress acknowledges that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, privately owned but government-sponsored enterprises, were central to the 2008 financial crisis, leading to a severe economic downturn and the loss of millions of jobs. In response, the Treasury Department, Federal Reserve Board, and FHFA placed the GSEs in conservatorship to take control of their operations. In response to the 2008 financial crisis, the government took control of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, leading to the loss of 7,500,000 jobs. The Treasury Department, Federal Reserve Board, and FHFA placed the GSEs in conservatorship, while the Obama Administration established a $400 billion commitment to purchase senior preferred stock in the enterprises. Additionally, Federal funds were used to cover losses at the enterprises, exceeding $110 billion in expenditures. The Obama Administration removed limits on Federal funds for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, resulting in taxpayers owning 80% of the GSEs. The government is using the enterprises for housing policy, reducing the likelihood of private ownership. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are now effectively government entities according to the Congressional Budget Office. The Obama Administration removed limits on Federal funds for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, resulting in taxpayers owning 80% of the GSEs. The government is using the enterprises for housing policy, reducing the likelihood of private ownership. The Congressional Budget Office concluded that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have effectively become government entities. The GSEs are expected to be a long-term drain on taxpayers due to market conditions and political mandates. Despite these liabilities, the Treasury Department and FHFA approved $6,000,000 compensation packages for the chief executive officers of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 2010. At the end of 2009, the Treasury Department and FHFA approved $6,000,000 compensation packages for the chief executive officers of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for 2010, which is significantly higher than the annual compensation of the President and Cabinet Secretary. Additionally, multi-million dollar compensation packages were also approved for other top executives of the GSEs, paid in cash instead of stock options. The Treasury Department and FHFA approved multi-million dollar compensation packages for top executives of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, payable in cash. FHFA determined no cash bonuses or long-term incentives for executives in 2008. The Strategic Plan includes a commitment to safe and sound operations. Section 1318(c) of the Act emphasizes financial safety and soundness. The FHFA's Strategic Plan for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 2008 includes a commitment to safe and sound operations. Section 1318(c) of the Act allows the Director of FHFA to withhold or escrow executive compensation for review. SEC. 3. REASONABLE COMPENSATION. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency will suspend 2010 compensation packages for executive officers of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Instead, a new compensation system will be established based on federal government pay rates. Additionally, there is a provision for clawing back 2009 compensation for executive officers. The Congress suggests that executive officers of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac should return any excess 2009 compensation to the Treasury. The Treasury will then transfer these amounts to reduce the national debt. The Congress recommends that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac executive officers return excess 2009 compensation to the Treasury, which will then transfer the amounts to reduce the national debt.
